title: Stepstowealth
author: Stepstowealth
content: Can self-custody be too difficult to practice by a crypto investor? Because I spoke to somebody about bitcoin and the person responded by saying that they are not too sure that they can trust their self to keep their investment safe because of their careless nature, and this got me thinking because can I call this person being very sincere or the person is just afraid to try. Everyone should be in-charge and control of their bitcoin investment, and if somebody knows that they cannot practice self custody then I don't believe that bitcoin should be what they are investing in because it is simply not safe for someone else to be helping you manage your investments in bitcoin.

comments.author: OmegaStarScream
comments.body: This is not something I would recommend doing but wallets are just getting easier to use. Even for self custody, you've got wallets allowing you to backup your wallet to the cloud (Google drive or iCloud) or I believe some wallets like Exodus, allow you to do the same process through email. Again, not something I would recommend but it really doesn't get easier than that.I'm saying the above assuming that the "concern" here is not the security of the assets from hackers but rather losing access to your own wallet of course.

comments.author: Smartprofit
comments.body: Quote from: Stepstowealth on October 26, 2024, 01:32:56 PMCan self-custody be too difficult to practice by a crypto investor? Because I spoke to somebody about bitcoin and the person responded by saying that they are not too sure that they can trust their self to keep their investment safe because of their careless nature, and this got me thinking because can I call this person being very sincere or the person is just afraid to try. Everyone should be in-charge and control of their bitcoin investment, and if somebody knows that they cannot practice self custody then I don't believe that bitcoin should be what they are investing in because it is simply not safe for someone else to be helping you manage your investments in bitcoin.In any case, every investor should take care of the security of their investments. For example, the owner of a deposit in a commercial bank should also take care that an intruder does not gain access to his banking application. The owner of real estate should also take care that fraudsters do not forge a general power of attorney and re-register the property rights. Owning any property requires responsibility. In the situation with storing Bitcoin, everything is more complicated, since when storing Bitcoin on your own, there is no intermediary (third party) at all to whom claims can later be made. Therefore, Bitcoin owners need additional training. They will need information about hardware wallets, cold wallets, the structure of the blockchain, private and public addresses, miner fees, and other information. Much of this information can be found on this forum.

comments.author: legiteum
comments.body: It doesn't, because they have options.Based on what we know about the proliferation of broker accounts and apps at places like Coinbase, Binance, PayPal, etc., not to mention the ETFs, it would appear that most consumers don't want self-custody and would instead prefer to keep an account secured by their own identity at a firm they trust.It's important to understand the phenomenon of the Anon Paradox, which states that consumers like anonymity for "small" money, and their personal identity connected to "big" money. In other words, if somebody wants to play around with say $50 in Bitcoin or some other digital currency, then they want this to be anonymous like the physical cash in their physical wallet. The reason is that they like the anonymity for spending it--that way they don't impart personal data when they buy something.But if somebody is keeping a large part of their life savings digital currency investments, they want this to be safe and they tend to want to enlist the services of a firm like Coinbase to guard their money for them because they would otherwise be afraid of losing the keys, or them being stolen, or them being beaten or murdered because of their physical possession of their keys (it's the same reason people don't hold their savings in piles of physical cash in their own home and instead use a bank).

comments.author: Ultegra134
comments.body: Wallets aren't that hard to use anymore, their setup is pretty straightforward, but this isn't the issue as some users already mentioned. I'm one of those people who have been careless in the past, losing an unknown number of wallets from 2013 to 2017, it's certainly more than five private keys/wallets, some of them were recovered, but others were lost. The issue with online wallets, exchanges or any kind of service is that you never know when they'll shut down or start requesting more documentation, refusing access to your funds with no valid reason.I personally didn't lose any money when I stored my Bitcoin on BitGo, which does provide you with the private keys, and on Bitstamp, both of which are reputed services, but did lose a reasonable amount of Bitcoin on the Xapo wallet, which refused access to my account even though I provided with everything they requested.

Everyone should be in-charge and control of their bitcoin investment, and if somebody knows that they cannot practice self custody then I don't believe that bitcoin should be what they are investing in because it is simply not safe for someone else to be helping you manage your investments in bitcoin. Honestly, why jump straight into total self-custody? It’s way better to take it easy and go step by step. Start with the basics, get a solid grip on security, and have some support at the beginning. This way, you can ease into it, build your confidence, and avoid risking everything all at once.

comments.author: Stalker22
comments.body: Self-custodying your crypto coins is a big responsibility, no doubt.  You gotta be the bank, the vault, and the security guard all in one.  But I think anyone can get the hang of it if they try.  Theres lots of stuff out there - videos, tutorials, forums - to help you get started. You can use hardware wallets for extra security. Or if you know your way around tech, you can make your own wallet on an air-gapped device. Either way, self-custody is the most secure way to hold your crypto, imho.
